title: Key trio helps Mystics put it all together for first WNBA championship
text:
CLOSE

WASHINGTON — The coach was adamant a WNBA championship wasn’t necessary to fulfill a lifelong basketball career.

Yet, with Mike Thibault — his suit, shirt and tie drenched in champagne and red, white and blue confetti still on the court — the Mystics coach acknowledged Washington’s championship over Connecticut "completes my résumé" but only "so you guys don't keep asking me about it."

The unassuming reserve from Belgium is one of the best players in the world, but she acts like she’s just there to help her teammates here and there.

Emma Meesseman was named Finals MVP after scoring 22 points on 9-for-13 shooting in the Mystics’ 89-78 victory over the Sun. She shot 57% from the field in the five-game series and scored at least 20 points in six of Washington’s nine playoff games.

The league’s best player endured not one, not two, but three herniated disks in her back during the Finals.

Elena Delle Donne, the 2015 and 2019 WNBA MVP, said it felt like she had a pole up her back but still had 21 points, nine rebounds, two assists and two blocks in the decisive game of the series.

"Have I told you lately that I love you?"



—@De11eDonne on what she said in her coach's ear moments after winning her first WNBA title pic.twitter.com/e5HvuKf0n8 — SportsCenter (@SportsCenter) October 11, 2019

Oh, it took more than those three for the Mystics to win the title. Kristi Toliver put a shaky start behind her and finished with 18 points. Natasha Cloud missed four 3-pointers in the first half but made two in the second half and finished with 18 points.

"One of the best things about this team is the camaraderie and the family atmosphere on this team," Thibault said. "They love each other. They played for each other. When we had our toughest moment tonight in the third quarter, we banded together, played like we had all year."

The 69-year-old coach is a basketball lifer, starting his coaching career in 1980 as an assistant for the Los Angeles Lakers where he was part of two championship teams. He has friends all over the NBA and attends Wizards games to catch up with coaches. He was an assistant with Chicago and Milwaukee and won a championship in the Continental Basketball Association.

He moved to the WNBA in 2002, spending 10 years with Connecticut. He earned WNBA Coach of the Year honors twice and reached the Finals twice, losing both times. He was fired in 2012.

"One phrase that was given to me by somebody in the organization at the time I got fired was that I owed them a championship," Thibault said. "I got mine first."

The @WashMystics head coach Mike Thibault talks with @sportsiren on how his squad was able to get it done on the BIGGEST stage! 👏#WNBApic.twitter.com/EwVZfSM8lr — WNBA (@WNBA) October 11, 2019

Thibault got married in 1982 after the Lakers’ championship; his son, Eric, a Mystics assistant coach, is getting married next week.

"Next week at his wedding, we’re going to put the trophy in the middle of the whole thing, too," Thibault said.

The Mystics drafted Meesseman in 2013, but after having played non-stop basketball in American and Europe for five consecutive seasons, she sat out the 2018 WNBA season to rest.

When she returned in 2019, she was labeled the missing piece who could propel the Mystics to a title after they lost in the 2018 Finals without her.

But she didn’t view herself as the missing piece.

"These playoffs were the moment that I really realized I have to take my responsibility and I can play," she said. "I've never really believed that because I know last year I would not be the same player this year. I just think that I really needed that break and to be home. So I would not have been able to bring what I brought now.”

She averaged 17.8 points in the five-game series, and when Washington needed someone to score in the second half Thursday, she was the one. She had 11 points in the third quarter, and she did it in a six-minute stretch that helped cut Connecticut’s nine-point lead to 64-62 heading into the fourth.

"The way she played tonight in the moments that she wanted the ball in the biggest moments, and a couple years ago she didn't," Toliver said. "And so that's a huge credit to her and her growth as a player and a person."

Delle Donne played in the 2014 Finals with Chicago and lost, and played in the 2018 Finals and lost. In 2014, she was slowed by a bad back, last season a bone bruise and another back issue in these Finals.

"I've contemplated long hours over why every time I get to a Finals something happens, and I think it's because I pissed the basketball gods off years ago when I decided to step away," she said. "So I'm hoping this ends this little drama that I've been having in the Finals."

Delle Donne scored 11 points in the second half, including six in the fourth quarter.

She wanted a trade from Chicago so she could closer to her Delaware home and her sister, Lizzie, who was born deaf, blind and with cerebral palsy and autism. The Mystics acquired Delle Donne in 2017.

"Lizzie has been my journey, and some people have never understood my decisions. Others have. But she's been my path, and somehow she's gotten me to this moment," Delle Donne said. "Another reason I can battle through injury is she's been dealt the worst cards possible with her disabilities, and every day she gets up, she smiles, she laughs, she loves. So she's always just been my inspiration."

Follow Jeff Zillgitt on Twitter @JeffZillgitt.
description: Head coach Mike Thibault, star Elena Delle Donne and Finals MVP Emma Meeseman guided the Mystics to the first WNBA championship in franchise history.
